title: 109_s2397
content: The Act titled "Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006" introduces Long-Term Care Trust Accounts under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This new part, Part IX, establishes Long-Term Care Trust Accounts. The Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006 establishes Long-Term Care Trust Accounts as exempt from taxation, subject to unrelated business income taxes. A Long-Term Care Trust Account is a trust for the exclusive benefit of a designated beneficiary meeting specific requirements. The Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006 establishes trust accounts for designated beneficiaries. Contributions must be in cash and within specified limits. The trustee must be a bank, insurance company, or demonstrate compliance with trust requirements. Trust assets cannot be invested in life insurance contracts, and individual account balances are nonforfeitable. The Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006 establishes trust accounts for designated beneficiaries with contribution limits. Trust assets must not be commingled except in specified funds, and distributions are restricted to chronically ill individuals. Contributions to all accounts cannot exceed $5,000 annually. The Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006 sets contribution limits for trust accounts, with adjustments for inflation starting in 2006. Contributions for all accounts are capped at $5,000 annually, and gift tax treatment is specified for chapters 12 and 13. The Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006 establishes contribution limits for trust accounts, with adjustments for inflation from 2006. Contributions are capped at $5,000 annually, and gift tax treatment is specified for chapters 12 and 13, including completed gifts to beneficiaries and excess contribution treatment. The Long-Term Care Trust Account Act of 2006 allows for qualified rollover contributions from other accounts and spouses within a 60-day period. Distributions from a Long-Term Care Trust Account are taxable income. Trust Account distributions may be included in gross income under specific conditions, such as for long-term care insurance premiums and qualified long-term care services for chronically ill individuals. No amount is included in gross income for distributions providing benefits for qualified long-term care services for chronically ill individuals. Cash distributions not exceeding expenses for such services are also not included in gross income. The distribution of amounts for qualified long-term care services is not included in gross income. Any excess amount is reduced by the ratio of expenses to distributions. Changes in beneficiaries or accounts within 60 days can be transferred to another Long-Term Care Trust Account for the same beneficiary or their spouse. Operating rules for Long-Term Care Trust Accounts include treating all accounts as one, treating distributions in a taxable year as one, and computing contract values at the end of the calendar year. Special rules apply for death and divorce situations. Rules similar to paragraphs (7) and (8) of section 220(f) apply. If a donor dies before the 5-year period after making excess contributions, the estate includes the contributions allocated post-death. An additional 25% tax is imposed on Long-Term Care Trust Account distributions included in gross income. The Long-Term Care Trust Account distributions included in gross income are subject to a 25% increase. Any payment from the account is not considered a medical care expense for tax deduction purposes. The designated beneficiary is the individual named at the start of account participation. If the beneficiary engages in a prohibited transaction, the account may lose its tax exemption status. For Long-Term Care Trust Accounts, custodial accounts or annuity contracts issued by qualified insurance companies can be treated as trusts if they meet specific requirements. Custodial accounts must be held by a bank or another approved entity. For Long-Term Care Trust Accounts, custodial accounts or annuity contracts can be treated as trusts. The person holding the assets of such account or annuity contract is considered the trustee. The trustee must report to the Secretary and the beneficiary on contributions, distributions, and other required matters. Tax on excess contributions to certain tax-favored accounts and annuities is governed by section 4973 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include Long-Term Care Trust Accounts as a new type of tax-favored account. Excess contributions to these accounts are subject to specific rules outlined in section 4973. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include Long-Term Care Trust Accounts as a new type of tax-favored account. Excess contributions to these accounts are subject to specific rules outlined in section 4973. Qualified rollover contributions exceeding the contribution limit are subject to a special rule where contributions returned before June 1 of the following year are not taken into account. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include Long-Term Care Trust Accounts under section 530A(i). The table of parts for subchapter F of chapter 1 has been updated to reflect this change. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include Long-Term Care Trust Accounts under section 530A(i). The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2005. Additionally, a refundable credit for contributions to Long-Term Care Trust Accounts has been introduced under section 35A of the Internal Revenue Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 now allows a credit for contributions to Long-Term Care Trust Accounts under section 530A. The credit is equal to 10 percent of the contributions for the taxable year, with a reduction based on adjusted gross income. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a credit for contributions to Long-Term Care Trust Accounts under section 530A. The credit is 10 percent of contributions for the taxable year, with a reduction based on adjusted gross income. Adjusted gross income is determined without regard to certain sections. No deduction is allowed for amounts used in calculating the credit. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item after section 35. Section 35A adds Contributions to Long-Term Care Trust Accounts. The amendments apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2005.
